Eat as much as you want.
Well, she was really suffering. The last couple years.

dialogues.text: Oh nothing, just this little video.

dialogues.text: No weird feet knuckles or stray hairs.

I didn't mean to accost you! I just wanted to intercept you in case you couldn't f

scenes.heading: INT. WARSAW HOTEL RESTAURANT - DAY

dialogues.text: We’re a relatively small group, which will be nice and intimate.
As I was saying, I'm James. I'll be your British tour guide through
18 I’m a scholar of Eastern European studies at Oxford.
Uh, my mother was a survivor of the camps and literally never spoke about it.
Thank you for sharing that, Marcia.
Uh hi, Diane and Mark Binder.
We were Mayflower Jews, was always my little joke.
And we were always interested in seeing where they lived, what this place looked like.
Yeah, not as glamorous, my side of the family. Sorry about that.
I guess you won’t be the only one on this trip, James.
Happy for t he company, Eloge.
But I did convert to Judaism, about ten years ago. I am actually
And to answer the inevitable question that you might be thinking, I am a survivor of the genocide.
No, sorry. I mean it in a good way.
Benji, I am an open book.
Anyway, I do have a unique story.
And in Winnipeg, I was helped by the Faintuchs, a Jewish family—
Yes, naturally, Benji. And when I learned about Judaism and the story of the Jewish people, I felt at peace for the first time since the war.
I didn’t think I would be crying before the tour even started.
Who the hell wants to follow that? (off their laughter)
Oh, Jesus man, don’t say that. 21
Anyway, our Grandma Dory was from here, she survived the war in the craziest fuckin way. In basements, hidden amongst the uncircumcised-
Yeah and everyone else died- her parents, her sisters, a brother.
It was fucked, essentially, is what it was.
Yeah, that's why we’re leaving the tour a
She was the coolest - just this fierce, no bullshit, fuckin take charge chick.
And I’ve been in kind of a funk since she died.
Yo, thank you Marcia, you’re a sweetheart.
So, just to keep things on track:
And Dave could never find the time cause he's got a high pressured job selling ad banners to the internet.
But I've been in such a shit place recently, so Dave swooped in, took some time off and arranged for us to join this geriatric Polish tou r with you fine people.
You know: She didn’t ask any of the other cousins to come here.
Yeah, she knew the two of us have a special connection, right
Yeah, I'm not really sure what she knew.

scenes.actionPreview: James leads the guys towards a corner of the restaurant: They arrive at a table o f four other tourists, who James addresses: I found them. Everyone, this is Benji and David. scenes.heading: EXT. WALICOW STREET - DAY

dialogues.text: Benji and David sit across from each othe r, eating rye soup-

The woman with the 'sadness in her eyes'.

No. And she just told you all this?
Yeah. And now she’s seeing this new guy, Darren, which you’d think she’d be

Yeah, she’s in a really weird place right now. 27 28 Anyway, she's super fuckin stressed right now because her husband left her last May, like completel

scenes.heading: EXT. WARSAW UPRISING MONUMENT - DAY

dialogues.text: This monument truly speaks to the tragic complexity of
These two supposed allies, brothers against a common enemy. But infighting and spite tore them apart.
You see, Stalin resented the resistance as they’d fought him for independence and so he stood back, l etting Germany crush the resistance in 63 short days. It’s harrowing.
Yo, Eloge, when you’re done, could you take a picture of me and Dave posing with the guys?
We should go pose with the guys, it’ll be hysterical.
How the fuck is it disrespectful?
Yeah, I don’t know if we should-
You look great, Benji. I got some good shots.
Well they’re twice the size of you.
I know! I need some back up!
I’m not a fighter, Benji, thank you.
Okay, well you can be a medic or something!
You sure you don’t wanna come up here?
Jesus, this is a real fuckin' sausage party. Marcia, come on up here!
You wanna work with Eloge on this dude’s leg?
Okay, we got these fuckin Nazis right where we want ‘em.
I can’t believe I’m doing this.
You sure don’t want to go up?
Oh, I feel bad, this is your tour. 33
Okay, everyone pick a pose and freeze in it so Dave could take a picture. Is that cool with you
You almost done Dave? My arms are gettin tired.
Thank you so much, dude. That was so fuckin fun.

scenes.actionPreview: The group approaches the dramatic Warsaw Uprising Monument-- massive bronze soldiers in battle positions. Polish history. The Warsaw Uprising was perhaps more tragic in the Russian response to the uprising than the German crushing of the rebellion. On Benji and David, listening— Back to James— Anywa

dialogues.text: I’m sorry I called you a light weight.
You were the only person who even

I didn’t care that you fell asleep. I was just happy you were there.

scenes.actionPreview: David reenters the room, freshly showered. Benji is still sleeping. David stands over his cousin, looking at him. In his sleep, Benji has a pained look on his face. Benji, dude. We gotta go. Train’s in an hour. Everyone’s downstairs. 41 42 Benji groans.

scenes.actionPreview: The group is waiting outside for the boys. Benji perks up when he sees everyone, his erratic charisma suddenly alighting.

scenes.actionPreview: The group walks throu gh the train station. Benji takes it all in like a little kid.

dialogues.text: Luckily, included in your tour fee, we all get first class seats — not too bad, huh?

scenes.heading: EXT. TRAIN - DAY

dialogues.text: And if we have time, I think
Yo du de, I think we should move.
I think we should move to a different train car.
Don’t you feel weird being in a first class car?
No. We paid for it. It’s not hurting anybody.
Yes, it’s fine. We’re fine. Sorry about that.
I just feel like — is no one else feeling this?
Just the creepy feeling of being, like,
Oh, come on, Benji, stop that—
Yeah, I don’t think everyone wants to hear that—

I’m not suggesting you should, Mark-
Because our lives are so fuckin pampered and privileged!
So what are we supposed to do about that?
Benji, why are you doing this?
I’m just sayin how I feel, Dave.
And why is that important now?
Yo, Dave, you used to feel everything.
We went to Jewy sleep-away camp together and he cried the whole first week cause he was homesick.
And I would have to hug him to sleep and talk about his sweet fuckin mom to calm him down.
I don’t think you’ll find much suffering back there either.
Of course. Of course. You know where to get off?
Yeah, Lublin Glowny? I must be mispronouncing it.

scenes.heading: EXT. STAIRS TO CASTLE - DAY

dialogues.text: I wan t today to be as vibrant as it is melancholic.

scenes.actionPreview: The group ascends the massive staircase that leads to the castle. Lublin has such a rich Jewish history. It was actually called The Jewish Oxford. It was diverse, intellectually and culturally. It was progressive, open, welcoming. And it’s hard to say whether the Jewish community was attracted to Lu

dialogues.text: Not all, but I do keep Shabbat.

You mean like benefit everyo ne or, like, me specifically?
I wanted to say that I’ve been thinking about what you said on the train.
You know, last year, my daughter married a very rich man-
-And she can barely have a conversation with any depth anymore.
Of course she has! Money’s like fuckin heroin for boring people.
Well, I don’t know what that means.
Hi, yes, I’m eavesdropping, is that okay?
Of course, Eloge, come on in!
I want to echo what Marcia said, if that’s all right. 56
Exactly. David, we numb ourselves to avoid thinking about the impact we have-
Ignoring the proverbial slaughter house to enjoy the steak, as it were-
Dave, we’re on a fuckin Holocaust tour.
If I can get everyone’s attention.
Try to imagine what could have been, the promise, the hope—

scenes.actionPreview: The group walks along the gorgeous bridge to the gate. David approaches Eloge: 55 You do all the customs? It’s mediative, it gives me a chance to unwind, to refocus. And you? The whole thing always seemed like a little archaic and arbitrary and mechanical to me. No offense. Up ahead, Marcia approach

scenes.heading: EXT. LUBLIN - MONTAGE

dialogues.text: The memories of Jewish life are here, but they’re hidden around this city, moments trapped in amber.
A former Yiddish theater. -A medical academy building, the site of a former Yeshiva 58
A former Yeshiva. -Hebrew letters in relief on the side of a building

scenes.actionPreview: Nocturne Op. 9 No. 2 plays over the following: There aren’t monuments or statues. The only synagogue is a now-defunct second floor office building. But there are little moments of history frozen in time, peeking out, waiting for us. Emblems of a people, of stories, of contributions. As he speaks, we

scenes.heading: EXT. GRAVEL STREET - AFTERNOON
scenes.actionPreview: In a wide tableau, the group ambles along this uneven path at the edge of town. Benji throws his arm around David and pinches his cheek.

scenes.heading: EXT. CEMETERY – DUSK

dialogues.text: So there’s a bit of a discrepancy about the founding of the cemetery but most have it pegged at 1541.
I read about it this morning.
He’s actually buried right back here.
You’re like completely knowledgeable about all this shit and it’s mad impressive and we all know that now but like –
But like these are real people.
I’m sorry, Benji, did I say something to upset you? 60
I mean, you know your shit, don’t get me wrong.
And, like, part of the problem, if we’re bein honest right now, with the
Don’t take this the wrong way or anything, but we’ve just been going from one touristy thing to another, not meeting anyone who’s
Benji, I’m sorry to say this, but that’s kind of what these tours are.
Dave signed up for the tour.
And it’s a mostly amazing tour,
That sounds like a great idea.
Yeah, dude, that’s what I’m talking about.
Um, if I can get everyone to j oin me over here.
And Benji had a wonderful idea of taking a moment of silence and placing a rock on Mr. Kopleman’s grave.
I think that’s a lovely idea.
But you can totally use it.
Yo, did you find one Marcia?
That’s very kind, than k you.
Is there something wrong with where I’m putting it?
Everyone knows it’s sacrilege to put a rock on the north side of a grave.
Well, that’s fine because I’m an atheist.

scenes.actionPreview: At the top of the hill is the Jewish cemetery, a rough patch of land with scattered tombsto nes. The group naturally fans out, taking it all in. Eloge lingers around James-- Think about that. Before the founding of the United States, before Shakespeare, before the locomotive. And, if I may, the olde

scenes.heading: EXT. RESTAURANT - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: Establish a lively restaurant in old town Lublin.

scenes.heading: INT. RESTAURANT - NIGHT

dialogues.text: And my father’s brother was the real brains of the family.
Yes, we stop here on every tour, the food is wonderful, but the music can be a little kitschy-
Yeah, it’s totally authentic to essentialize a 5000 year old history with a jappy Bar Mitzvah song. Pl ease continue, Marcia.
Ah, now the song’s over. Just as I’m done, my usual good timing.
That story is amazing Marcia. The ingenuity to create a pharmacy because he was barred from medical school speaks volumes about the immigrant experience.
I can attest to that, absolutely. 65
Oh yes, my great uncle came off the boat from Poland, landed in
And made money by taking the furniture that rich people threw out on the street, refurbishing it and reselling.
And apparently he ended up selling some of it
Yeah, Grandma Dory, who’s house we’re seeing on Thursday, was just amazing too.
Yeah, she was just one of these bygone, realist types you don’t see anymore. Blunt and tough— I was scared shitless of her my whole childhood.
And a similar kind of story to you
Yeah, but she was like “fuck this.”
You’re making it sound like she led a junta
I used to speak to her every
Oh, Marcia, I’m sorry, fuck them. I wouldn’t miss a week. She was tough on me.
But grandma never pitied herself — she said she was grateful for her struggle. 67
Um… she was just speaking generally.
I think she was just talking about the immigrant experience.
I lived in my mom’s basement.
Yo, Benji, sh e was talking about immigrants, that’s all.
She sounds like a fascinating person.
I think we should toast to her.
He wants to be good – you can see the spark, do you know what I mean?
Forgive me if I don’t see this magical spark.
Yes! He’s always been like, up and down. Like he’s sensitive and he sees people so clearly but then you say the wrong thing and something switches.
No, it's okay. David, I'm sorry.
Like six months ago. My aunt Leah --
Did you know he plays piano?

scenes.actionPreview: A pianist plays the familiar Hava Nagila . We move off of the pianist to find our group sitting in this cozy, old style restaurant. They are through dinner, sipping drinks. The mood feels light, except Benji who is stewing. He was rejected from medical school because of quotas, you know, on Jewish d

scenes.heading: EXT. RESTAURANT - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: David emerges from the restaurant, alone. He can faintly hear Benji's music from inside the restaurant. As David begins walking back to the hotel, Benji's music 65B 65B becomes more insistent and grating, needling it's way into David's subconscious.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL ENTRANCE - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: A bastardized version of Benji's music continues. From inside the lobby, we see David enter the Lubli n hotel.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: David enters the room and the music in his head abruptly stops. He stands there in frustration for a minute. He walks to his bag and fishes out one of his pills. He dry swallows it. It gets caught in his throat and makes him choke a bit. He hits at his throat, pissed and miserable- LATER It’s dark.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: It's the middle of the night. David is sleeping. He hears Benji enter the room and he stirs awake. Not wanting to engage with Benji, David lies very still. He hears Benji rifle through some stuff and then leave the room. David is confused. He sits up — Benji is gone. David looks at the clock — it’s

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HALLWAY - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: David peeks his head out the room and looks down the empty hallway.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: David is throwing on clothes, irritated.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HALLWAY - MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: David is walking through the hallway, looking for Benji.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN LOBBY - MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: David is talking to the front desk, who haven’t seen Benji.

dialogues.text: David is stewing in his bed, pissed and worried about Benji.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL ROOM - MORNING
scenes.actionPreview: David is sleeping, sitting up in bed. He had a rough night. Suddenly, the room phone rings. He startles awake. Dude, we’re all downstairs waitin on you.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL ELEVATOR – MORNING
scenes.actionPreview: David, now dressed, rides the elevator down. He’s pissed.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN LOBBY

dialogues.text: Dude, I’m sorry. You were fast asleep when I left.
Well you scared the shit outta me,
Everybody’s down so early, I love that.

scenes.actionPreview: — MORNING David exits the elevator and walks to the lobby: Benji is there, sitting with the group. 74 75 Your alarm clock didn’t go off? No, my phone died because I didn’t plug it in because I spent the night looking for you. Where the fuck were you? Benji. I was just hangin with Marcia. I didn’t wa

scenes.heading: INT. VAN - DAY

dialogues.text: So, this is going to be a taxing day.

scenes.actionPreview: The van drives on the outskirts of Lublin. James is facing back to address the group. David sits up front, Benji sits in the back. If you’ve never been to a concentration camp, it can obviously be pretty overwhelming. 75 But reactions fall along a broad spectrum from numbing to complete distress and

scenes.heading: EXT. MAJDANEK - DAY

dialogues.text: Well, it's weird to say it, but we're here.

scenes.actionPreview: The bus pulls in to the camp parking lot. It’s eerily sparse. Majdanek is essentially a preserved camp, unadorned with the museum style of other Holocaust sites.

scenes.heading: EXT. PARKING LOT - DAY

dialogues.text: Majdanek is literally only two miles from the Lublin town square.

scenes.actionPreview: The group files off the van. Can you imagine? Life was continuing, a bustling city, two miles from these grounds. The group takes this in. The group walks towards the entrance and we get a full sense of the scope of this unnerving place. Push past them to see the massive town just beyond the barbed

scenes.heading: EXT. ENTRANCE AREA - DAY

dialogues.text: I might be a little sparser with my information overload today.

scenes.actionPreview: The group walks toward the barracks. Majdanek, the Nazis had taken nearly all of the prisoners to camps in the West. In their haste, the SS didn't destroy the evidence. So, unlike other camps, Majdanek is... well preserved , for lack of a better phrase. Benji and David look around, cowed by the enor

scenes.heading: INT. BARRACKS - DAY

dialogues.text: James reads a passage from a survivor.

scenes.actionPreview: The group approaches the exhibition barrack. Built to fit 250 people. Often housed 500 and sometimes even beyond 1000.

scenes.heading: INT. UNDRESSING ROOM - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The group stands in the bare windowless room.

scenes.heading: INT. SHOWER ROOM - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The group enters this dank, low ceiling room. 78 LATER James reads another harrowing personal recount.

scenes.heading: INT. GAS CHAMBER - DAY

dialogues.text: The blue stains on the walls are residue from Zyklon B.

scenes.actionPreview: The group inside this considerably darker room. The group looks around silently, in various stages of nausea. Benji unconsciously puts his hand on David’s shoulder.

scenes.heading: INT. CREMATORIUM – DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The group looks at the crematorium, body sized ovens, compl etely preserved. James doesn’t say anything.

scenes.heading: INT. SHOE DISPLAY BARRACK - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: In this barrack, there are a display of discarded victims’ shoes. Benji and David are now standing next to each other. They stare at the mound of shoes together. It’s overwhelming.

scenes.heading: EXT. MAUSOLEUM - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The group arrives at the enormous spaceship-like Mausoleum. They stand under it, dwarfed by the structure. We see them fro m behind in a wide.

scenes.heading: INT. VAN - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The group rides back to the hotel. They are all in various stages of shell-shock. As we move down the van, we see David sitting next to Benji. Benji is staring out the window and openly crying. David is heartbroken. 78 79

scenes.heading: EXT. LUBLIN HOTEL - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The group walks towards the entrance.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL - DAY

dialogues.text: If we can gather up here for a minute?
Well, I’m comforted that we all shared that with each other.
That’s right — Benji and David are staying here for the night and finishing their pilgrimage to their grandmother’s house tomorrow.
Yeah man, shit, I’m gonna miss all you guys.
Y ou’re a very special person.
Yo, that means so much to me, man. I feel like you were some kind of brilliant sage in another life.
Benji, I wanna say, I’ve been doing these tours for five years and you’re the first person that’s given me any actionable feedback.
And I resisted in the moment but I haven’t been able put it out of my mind.

scenes.actionPreview: The group enters the lobby. The group gathers around James in the lobby. No one wants to respond. The group nods, understanding. James notices Eloge: I know you don’t have the same advantage of distance. I’m just glad I’m not completely inured to this kind of thing. I think that would be worse. Marc

scenes.heading: EXT. LUBLIN - AFTERNOON
scenes.actionPreview: The boys amble around Lublin. There’s a nice thawing between them. They walk above the Czechówka River mural, a parallel black hole universe of the figures below. 81 82

scenes.heading: EXT. OUTDOOR MARKET - AFTERNOON

dialogues.text: The boys leave the bazaar, Benji is wearing the hat.

scenes.actionPreview: At a makeshift bazaar, Benji tries on a funny Polish folk hat. David snaps a picture of it. Benji explains that’s he’s gonna buy the hat. David says, “Why would you buy the hat? I just took the picture. Do you really need to own that hat?”

scenes.heading: EXT. HILL OVERLOOKING CITY - DUSK
scenes.actionPreview: The boys eat greasy shawarma and trudge up the hill. The sun is setting behind them.

scenes.heading: EXT. BREWERY STREET - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: The boys walk under illuminated flowers and butterflies. Benji jumps to try to swat a butterfly - he doesn't even come close as David laughs.

scenes.heading: EXT. LUBLIN STREET OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: The boys are on the outskirts of town, surrounded by some taller buildings. Benji nods over to the building as a SMOKER walks out and lights up a cigarette. 82 83

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN BUILDING LOBBY - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: A SECURITY GUARD leans against a desk. Pan off him to see our smoker enter the building and, in tow, Benji and David, like idiots trying to act casual. They nod at the security guard who couldn't care less and follow the smoker to the elevator bank.

scenes.heading: INT. ELEVATOR - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: Benji and David enter the elevator with the smoker and press the top floor. They all wait in the elevator in an awkward silence. Benji looks like an idiot in his hat. The smoker casually starts a chat:

scenes.heading: EXT. ROOF - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: A quiet rooftop overlooking Lublin. We slowly pan to see a rusty, industrial door. We now push steadily toward the door, which begins jiggling. Suddenly, it pops open and the boys emerge-

scenes.heading: EXT. ROOF – NIGHT

dialogues.text: No, broheim, you’re connecting to real shit.
Shit, you know what I think that is?
Way down there: can you see it?
So what are you thinking about doing when you get back to
I mean, like, what's your plan?
Yo, dude, gimme that if you’re just gonna stare at it.
Yeah, so, like, when I get back, it’s gonna be pretty busy.
Yeah, my buddy Tim is reroofing his house and I’m probably gonna help out with that.
Yeah, but it’s gonna be sweet when it’s finished, you kn ow?
Uh, go back to my job?
Cool, so I’ll look forward to speaking to you in six months.
You know what it means, man.
Yo, I don’t wanna start anything.
Yeah, I know. It was awful. Who the fuck wants to cry about everything?
Dave! You’re not listening to me.
Benji, I have a son and a wife and a job. I can’t just, like, hang out with you all night, every night.
But you, like, literally never visit me.
Yeah, but it’s New York City, it’s the more logical place to visit than fucking Binghamton, all due respect.
Why don’t you care about me anymore?
What does that mean? I do fucking care about you!
I never hear from you anymore.
I’m standing three inches from you!
Yeah, bu t you only came here with me because I tried to kill myself.
Yeah, well it scared the shit out of me! I walk around with this terrible image of you in my head and, yeah, I don’t want to fucking lose you, okay!?
I don’t understand why you would ever do anything so fucking stupi d to yourself... (chokes back tears)
If I had your mind, I’d be fucking president.
Do you see how people love you?
I would give anything to know what that feels like.
But you light up a room and then you shit on everything inside of it. CUE: Chopin’s Nocturne Op. 55 No. 1

scenes.actionPreview: At the edge of the roof, the g uys pass a joint back and forth. Benji’s still in his Polish hat. I’m glad we went there today. Is that weird to say? It’s living. You need to do more of that. David nods and takes another hit. He notices something in the distance. 83 84 Oh, shit— Now we see it too. Ov

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL HALLWAY - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: In slow motion, following the boys as they make their way back to their room.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT
scenes.actionPreview: The boys enter their hotel room silently. LATER David is lying on his bed, reading on his phone. Benji emerges from the bathroom, having showered. The mood is bleak. David grabs his shit and walks into the bathroom. The shower turns on. LATER The boys are asleep in their separate beds.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL ROOM – MORNING
scenes.actionPreview: The next morning, David and Benji are packing up their stuff. They don’t speak to each other. 90 91

scenes.heading: INT. LOBBY DINING AREA - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The boys silently eat their complimentary breakfast in the hotel dining area. David’s phone buzzes. He checks it.

scenes.heading: INT. LUBLIN HOTEL - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: Through the window of the lobby, we see David and Benji load their bags into the trunk of an old, colorful taxi.

scenes.heading: EXT. COUNTRYSIDE - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The taxi passes through the countryside, passing a little road marker for Krasnystaw.

scenes.heading: INT. TAXI - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The boys are in the back of the taxi on the way to their grandma’s town.

scenes.heading: EXT. KRASNYSTAW TOWN SQUARE - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The taxi pulls up to the town square. It’s got a quiet mid- day feeling. Shops line the square along with simple, three story apartment buildings. The guys step out of the taxi and get their bags from the trunk.

scenes.heading: EXT. TOWN SQUARE – DAY

dialogues.text: I don’t see any numbers anywhere. (off his phone) I think it might be around this way: 91

scenes.actionPreview: The boys, holding their luggage, traverse the town square. 92

scenes.heading: EXT. SIDE STREET NEAR CHURCH - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: David leads Benji around the corner, passing the St. Francis Xavier Church, which has a massive wooden cross erected in the parking lot. David directs them toward an alley.

scenes.heading: EXT. ALLEY IN FRONT OF HOUSE - DAY

dialogues.text: Yeah. I don't know what I pictured.
You know, she slapped me once.
Yeah, I was late to meet her for dinner.
But it was the best thing that ever happened to me.
Let’s put a stone on the stoop.
I mean let’s get a little stone and put it on her stoop. To say we were here.
Yo, I think he’s yelling at us.
What the fuck was that about?
So why did you put the rocks in front of the door?
Oh - it’s a Jewish tradition. When you visit someone’s grave, you’re supposed to place a stone on it. To signify that you were ther e.
Yes, but she is not buried under the door.

scenes.actionPreview: They approach a little alley that looks like it hasn't changed in a hundred years. David points to a little address above a door - 25. They are trying to have a feeling about the place but it’s not coming. Just like 15 minutes. And also I was pretty high. It was at the Hudson restaurant. On third Av

scenes.heading: EXT. KRASNYTAW TOWN SQUARE - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The boys walk through the town square with their bags. They exit frame and the town continues on without them...

scenes.heading: I/E. TAXI
scenes.actionPreview: - NEAR KRASNYSTAW - DAY The boys in a taxi on their way back to Warsaw Airport.

scenes.heading: I/E. TAXI - WARSAW
scenes.actionPreview: We see the sign for Warsaw Chopin Airport. The taxi turns off the exit.

scenes.heading: INT. WARSAW AIRPORT - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The boys walk through the airport. They are not speaking but seem comfortable in each other’s presence.

scenes.heading: INT. AIRPLANE - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The boys are awake on the plane. Each lost in his own thoughts.

scenes.heading: INT. JFK GATE – DAY
scenes.actionPreview: The boys exit the gate with the other passengers. They walk through the airport.

scenes.heading: INT. JFK BAGGAGE AREA - DAY

dialogues.text: Hey, I was thinking: why don’t we grab a cab back to the city and you could come over for dinner?
Why the fuck did you do that?
I’m gonna be fine, man. Okay?

scenes.actionPreview: The boys are near the exit of the airport. 96 97 I know Priya would want to see you and Abe would love to tell you every fact about the Empire State building. Benji laughs. Benji looks around, considering. Well let’s at le ast split a cab back to the city and I could drop you at Penn Station for you

scenes.heading: INT. CAB - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: David is in a cab going back home. He is looking out the window.

scenes.heading: INT. CAB - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: David passes LeFrak City and the massive Machpelah cemetery. All this Jewish history right next door- upward mobility and death, the cycle. David takes it all in, a part of it all.

scenes.heading: EXT. BROOKLYN STREET - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: David walks down his street, towards his apartment. He stops in front of his building, takes out the stone and places it on his stoop.

scenes.heading: INT. APARTMENT - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: David enters his apartment and drops his bags. He calls out to his family that he has come home. 99 100 Priya and Abe run in and embrace him. He lifts his son into the air. He kisses his wife. His life seems so nice.

scenes.heading: INT. JFK AIRPORT - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: Back at the airport, in a repeat of our opening shot, we are slowly zooming in on a crowd of travelers as the music rises. As we zoom in, we notice that Benji is sitting alone on the airport bench where we first met him. He’s looking around, watching the strangers go by. Anyone can be a friend. We z
